# ANSI Escape Code Generator Module

## Purpose

This module generates ANSI character codes for printing colors and controlling terminal output. It provides a convenient Python interface for working with ANSI escape sequences to add colors, styles, and cursor control to terminal applications.

## Overview

The module implements ANSI escape code generation based on the [ANSI escape code standard](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code). It provides classes and functions to generate escape sequences for:

- Text foreground colors
- Text background colors  
- Text styling (bright, dim, normal)
- Cursor movement and positioning
- Screen and line clearing
- Terminal title setting

## Constants

The module defines key ANSI escape sequence prefixes:

```python
CSI = '\033['  # Control Sequence Introducer
OSC = '\033]'  # Operating System Command
BEL = '\a'     # Bell character
```

## Core Functions

### `code_to_chars(code)`

Converts a numeric ANSI code to a complete escape sequence.

**Parameters:**
- `code`: Integer ANSI code

**Returns:** String containing the full ANSI escape sequence

**Example:**
```python
code_to_chars(31)  # Returns '\033[31m' (red foreground)
```

### `set_title(title)`

Generates an escape sequence to set the terminal window title.

**Parameters:**
- `title`: String title for the terminal window

**Returns:** String containing the title-setting escape sequence

### `clear_screen(mode=2)`

Generates an escape sequence to clear the terminal screen.

**Parameters:**
- `mode`: Integer clearing mode (default: 2)
  - `0`: Clear from cursor to end of screen
  - `1`: Clear from cursor to beginning of screen  
  - `2`: Clear entire screen

**Returns:** String containing the screen clearing escape sequence

### `clear_line(mode=2)`

Generates an escape sequence to clear the current line.

**Parameters:**
- `mode`: Integer clearing mode (default: 2)
  - `0`: Clear from cursor to end of line
  - `1`: Clear from cursor to beginning of line
  - `2`: Clear entire line

**Returns:** String containing the line clearing escape sequence

## Classes

### `AnsiCodes`

Base class that automatically converts numeric ANSI codes to escape sequences upon instantiation.

**Behavior:**
- Scans class attributes for numeric codes
- Converts them to full escape sequences using `code_to_chars()`
- Sets instance attributes with the converted sequences

### `AnsiCursor`

Provides methods for cursor movement and positioning.

**Methods:**
- `UP(n=1)`: Move cursor up n lines
- `DOWN(n=1)`: Move cursor down n lines  
- `FORWARD(n=1)`: Move cursor forward n columns
- `BACK(n=1)`: Move cursor back n columns
- `POS(x=1, y=1)`: Position cursor at coordinates (x, y)

### `AnsiFore`

Defines foreground (text) color codes.

**Standard Colors:**
- `BLACK`, `RED`, `GREEN`, `YELLOW`, `BLUE`, `MAGENTA`, `CYAN`, `WHITE`
- `RESET`: Reset to default foreground color

**Extended Colors:**
- `LIGHTBLACK_EX`, `LIGHTRED_EX`, `LIGHTGREEN_EX`, etc.
- Note: Extended colors are well-supported but not part of the official standard

### `AnsiBack`

Defines background color codes with the same color options as `AnsiFore`.

### `AnsiStyle`

Defines text styling codes:
- `BRIGHT`: Bold/bright text
- `DIM`: Dimmed text
- `NORMAL`: Normal intensity
- `RESET_ALL`: Reset all formatting

## Global Instances

The module provides pre-instantiated objects for immediate use:

```python
Fore = AnsiFore()      # Foreground colors
Back = AnsiBack()      # Background colors  
Style = AnsiStyle()    # Text styles
Cursor = AnsiCursor()  # Cursor control
```

## Usage Examples

```python
# Print colored text
print(Fore.RED + "This is red text" + Style.RESET_ALL)

# Move cursor and print
print(Cursor.UP(2) + Cursor.FORWARD(10) + "Positioned text")

# Clear screen
print(clear_screen())

# Set terminal title
print(set_title("My Application"))
```

## Notes and Suggestions

- **Compatibility**: ANSI escape codes work on most Unix-like systems and modern Windows terminals
- **Reset Codes**: Always use `Style.RESET_ALL` or appropriate reset codes to avoid formatting bleeding into subsequent output
- **Extended Colors**: The `*_EX` color variants may not work on all terminals
- **Error Handling**: Consider adding validation for cursor position bounds and color code ranges
- **Performance**: For high-frequency output, consider caching frequently used escape sequences
